comment_text.mn10:1.1: This discourse is copied at DN 22, where the section on the four noble truths has been expanded with material mostly drawn from MN 141. These discourses are the most influential texts for modern Theravada meditation, prompting countless modern commentaries. Comparative study of the several parallel versions reveals that this discourse, while comprised almost entirely of early material, was compiled in this form as one of the latest texts in the Pali suttas. | While mindfulness is always useful (SN 46.53:15.4), the “establishment of mindfulness” (satipaṭṭhāna) refers especially to a conscious development of contemplative practices based on mindfulness, i.e. “mindfulness meditation” or simply “meditation”.
comment_text.mn10:2.1: The phrase ekāyano maggo (“path to convergence”) is given multiple meanings in commentaries and ancient translations. Outside of satipaṭṭhāna, it is used in only one context in Pali, where it means to “come together with” (MN 12:37.5). At SN 47.18:3.4 the phrase is spoken by Brahmā, which suggests it was a Brahmanical term. At Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.4.11—a passage full of details shared with the suttas—it means a place where things unite or converge. Thus satipaṭṭhāna leads to everything “coming together as one”. In other words, as seventh factor of the noble eightfold path, it leads to samādhi, the eighth factor (SN 45.1:3.9; see also MN 44:12.3).
comment_text.mn10:3.2: The idiom kāye kāyānupassī, literally “one who observes a body in the body” refers to focusing on a specific aspect of embodied experience, such as the breath, the postures, etc. | “Keen” (or “ardent”, ātāpī) implies effort, while “aware” (sampajāno) is the wisdom of understanding situation and context. | “Covetousness and displeasure” (abhijjhādomanassaṁ) are the strong forms of desire and aversion that are overcome by sense restraint in preparation for meditation.
comment_text.mn10:3.3: “Feelings” (vedanā) are the basic tones of pleasant, painful, or neutral, not the complexes we call “emotions”.
comment_text.mn10:3.4: “Mind” (citta) is simple awareness. In meditation contexts, “mind” is often similar in meaning to samādhi.
comment_text.mn10:3.5: “Principles” (dhammā) are the natural “systems” of cause and effect that underlie the “teachings”. The renderings “mind objects” or “mental qualities” are incorrect, as many of the things spoken of in this section are neither mind objects nor mental qualities. “Phenomena” is a possible translation, but the emphasis is not on the “appearance” of things, but on the “principles” governing their conditional relations.
comment_text.mn10:4.2: The situation here—a mendicant gone to the forest—establishes that this practice takes place in the wider context of the Gradual Training. Indeed, this whole sutta can be understood as an expansion of this phrase, mentioned briefly at DN 2:67.3.
comment_text.mn10:4.3: The most fundamental meditation instruction. Notice how the Buddha phrases it: not “concentrate on the breath” as an object, but rather “breathing” as an activity to which one brings mindfulness. The stages of breath meditation are not meant to be done deliberately, but to be observed and understood as the natural process of deepening meditation.
comment_text.mn10:4.4: In the beginning, the breath is somewhat rough and coarse. The Pali idiom is “long” and “short” breath, but in English we usually say to breathe “heavily” or “lightly”.
comment_text.mn10:4.5: Over time, the breath becomes more subtle and soft.
comment_text.mn10:4.6: Contextually the idiom “whole body” (sabbakāya) here refers to the breath, marking the fuller and more continuous awareness that arises with tranquility. Some practitioners, however, interpret it as the “whole physical body”, broadening awareness to encompass the movement and settling of energies throughout the body.
comment_text.mn10:4.7: The “physical process” (kāyasaṅkhāra) is the breath itself (SN 41.6:1.8). This can become so soft as to be imperceptible.
comment_text.mn10:4.8: Text has “long” and “short”, but “deep” and “shallow” or “heavy” and “light” are more idiomatic for describing the breath in English.
comment_text.mn10:5.1: “Internally” is one’s own body, “externally” the bodies of others, or external physical phenomena. This distinction is applied broadly in Buddhist meditation, but it is more relevant in some contexts than others. In the case of the breath, one is focusing on one’s own breath, but when contemplating, say, a dead body, or the material elements, there is more of an external dimension. Starting with “me” in here and the “world” out there, this practice dissolves this distinction so that we see we are of the same nature as everything else.
comment_text.mn10:5.2: This is the vipassanā (“insight” or “discernment”) dimension of meditation, observing not just the rise and fall of phenomena, but also their conditioned “nature” as being “liable” (-dhamma) to impermanence. The meaning of this passage is explained at (SN 47.42). Apart from these passages, vipassanā in satipaṭṭhāna pertains specially to the observation of principles.
comment_text.mn10:5.3: Mindfulness meditation leads to a range of knowledges as detailed by Anuruddha at SN 52.6 and SN 52.11–24. An arahant is “independent” of any attachment (eg. MN 143), but satipaṭṭhāna is also taught to give up dependency on views of the past and future (DN 29:40.1).
comment_text.mn10:6.1: In early Pali, this practice is found only in the two Satipaṭṭhānasuttas and the closely related Kāyagatāsatisutta (MN 119). It is practiced by developing a reflexive awareness of one’s posture and activity as it proceeds, often assisted by moving slowly and carefully.
comment_text.mn10:8.1: “Situational awareness” (sampajañña) understands the context and purpose of activities. The main examples here illustrate the activities of daily monastic life: leaving the monastery on almsround, restraint while in the town, care wearing the robes, then mindfully eating and going to the toilet.
comment_text.mn10:10.1: This practice is intended to counter sexual desire and obsession. The primary focus is on one’s own body, rather than another’s body, although that can be brought in also. By focusing on aspects of our body that we normally prefer to ignore, we move towards a healthy sense of acceptance and neutrality towards our body.
comment_text.mn10:10.2: Thirty-one parts are mentioned in early texts, later expanded to thirty-two with the addition of the “brain” (matthaluṅga).
comment_text.mn10:10.3: The “bag with openings at both ends” is the body. Not all the varieties of grains and beans can be positively identified.
comment_text.mn10:12.2: While meditation on the elements is commonly taught in early texts, this phrase is found only in the two Satipaṭṭhānasuttas and the Kāyagatāsatisutta. Detailed instructions are found in such suttas as MN 28 and MN 140. This meditation works in any posture, whereas breath meditation is best done sitting, to allow the breath to become still.
comment_text.mn10:12.3: This gruesome image shows that butchery of cows was a normal feature of ancient Indian life. | A wide range of skilled workers have an “apprentice”, including potters, goldsmiths, accountants, carpenters, magicians, etc. The word is antevāsī, literally “one who dwells within”, suggesting that apprentices would stay with their teacher. The same word is used for a monastic student.
comment_text.mn10:14.1: Cremation was expensive and not available to everyone. Bodies might be left in the charnel ground for a variety of reasons, such as local customs, lack of funds, or in cases of inauspicious death such as murder or execution. This is still seen in some places today, and monastics occasionally take the opportunity to practice meditation beside a corpse. However the wording of the Pali sounds like an imaginative exercise.
comment_text.mn10:14.2: The observed corpse is not gendered. The purpose is not to become repulsed by an objectified other, but to understand the mortality of one’s own body.
comment_text.mn10:30.1: It takes decades for bones to rot to powder, again suggesting it is an imaginative contemplation.
comment_text.mn10:32.1: Literally “a feeling among the feelings”; the practice shows that the meditator contemplates specific feelings as they occur.
comment_text.mn10:32.2: Pali employs direct quotes to indicate reflexive awareness: you feel the feeling and you know that you feel the feeling. It does not mean that you have to literally say “I feel a pleasant feeling”, although some adopt that as a meditation method.
comment_text.mn10:32.5: Feelings “of the flesh” (sāmisa) are associated with the body and sensual desires (SN 36.31:4.1).
comment_text.mn10:32.6: Feelings “not of the flesh” (nirāmisa) are associated with renunciation and especially with the jhānas and liberation (SN 36.31:5.1).
comment_text.mn10:32.8: This would include the feelings of loss, doubt, and dejection that can occur during the spiritual path (see MN 44:28.6).
comment_text.mn10:32.10: The feeling of the fourth jhāna and higher liberations (SN 36.31:8.2).
comment_text.mn10:34.1: In Buddhist theory, awareness of the presence or absence of qualities such as greed is explained on three levels. There is the simple happenstance of whether greed is present at that time or not. Then there is the mind freed of greed through the power of absorption. Finally there is the liberation from greed which comes with full awakening.
comment_text.mn10:34.8: The mind is “constricted internally” due to dullness and “scattered externally” due to the distractions of desire (SN 51.20:18.1).
comment_text.mn10:34.10: The following terms “expansive” (mahaggata), “supreme” (anuttara), “immersed” (samāhita), and “freed” (vimutta) all refer to states of absorption and/or awakening.
comment_text.mn10:36.2: The Satipaṭṭhānavibhaṅga of the Pali Abhidhamma only mentions the hindrances and awakening factors in this section (Vb 7). This, together with a range of other evidence, suggests that this was the original content of the observation of principles.
comment_text.mn10:36.4: Here causality is introduced. In the contemplation of mind, the meditator was aware of the presence or absence of desire in the mind. Now they look deeper, investigating the cause of desire and understanding how to be free of it forever. This contemplation of the “principles” of cause and effect is the distinctive feature of this section.
comment_text.mn10:36.6: The Buddhist schools debated whether this included physical tiredness or not. The Theravada argued that it was purely a mental laziness, as even the Buddha got sleepy.
comment_text.mn10:38.4: “Form” (rūpa) is one’s own body and the external material world experienced through the senses. More subtly, it represents the “appearance” of physical phenomena, even when experienced solely in the mind as color, visions, etc.
comment_text.mn10:38.6: “Perception” (saññā) is the recognition or interpretation of experience in terms of meaningful wholes. We see, for example, “color” yet we perceive a “person”. In the Vinaya we find many examples where a person perceived things in one way, yet they turned out to be something else.
comment_text.mn10:38.7: In the five aggregates, saṅkhārā is a synonym for “volition” (cetanā). The traditions later used it as a catch-all category for everything that does not fit in the other aggregates. In the suttas, however, the purpose of the aggregates is not to classify everything that exists, but to contemplate aspects of experience that we tend to identify as a “self”.
comment_text.mn10:40.3: At SN 35.232:3.2 the “fetter that arises dependent on both” is identified as “desire and lust” (chandarāga).
comment_text.mn10:42.1: These seven factors that lead to awakening (bojjhaṅgā, SN 46.5) are commonly presented in opposition to the five hindrances (eg. SN 46.2, SN 46.23, SN 46.55).
comment_text.mn10:42.3: “Mindfulness” includes the recollection of the teachings (SN 46.3:1.8) as well as mindfulness meditation.
comment_text.mn10:42.4: Likewise, this includes the inquiry into dhammas as “teachings” as well as “phenomena” or “principles”.
comment_text.mn10:44.1: Due to their development of the two wings of samatha and vipassanā meditation as described in this sutta, practised in the context of the teaching and training as a whole, the meditator realizes the four noble truths at the moment of stream-entry.
comment_text.mn10:44.3: Following this section, DN 22:17.4 announces the end of the first recitation section, and goes on to expand each of the four noble truths in detail.
comment_text.mn10:46.1: The emphasis is on “develop in this way” (evaṁ bhāveyya), that is, with the full practice including deep absorption as the culmination of the path as a whole.
comment_text.mn10:46.3: A similar promise of results in at most seven years is found at DN 22:22.3, DN 25:22.9, and MN 85:59.3; and at most ten years at AN 10.46:7.3.

translation_text.mn10:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Kurus, near the Kuru town named Kammāsadamma.
translation_text.mn10:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
translation_text.mn10:2.1: “Mendicants, the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are the path to convergence. They are in order to purify sentient beings, to get past sorrow and crying, to make an end of pain and sadness, to discover the system, and to realize extinguishment.
translation_text.mn10:3.2: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
translation_text.mn10:3.3: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
translation_text.mn10:3.4: They meditate observing an aspect of the mind—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
translation_text.mn10:3.5: They meditate observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
translation_text.mn10:4.1: And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of the body?
translation_text.mn10:4.2: It’s when a mendicant—gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut—sits down cross-legged, sets their body straight, and establishes mindfulness in their presence.
translation_text.mn10:4.3: Just mindful, they breathe in. Mindful, they breathe out.
translation_text.mn10:4.4: Breathing in heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing in heavily.’ Breathing out heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing out heavily.’
translation_text.mn10:4.5: When breathing in lightly they know: ‘I’m breathing in lightly.’ Breathing out lightly they know: ‘I’m breathing out lightly.’
translation_text.mn10:4.6: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing the whole body.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing the whole body.’
translation_text.mn10:4.7: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in stilling the physical process.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out stilling the physical process.’
translation_text.mn10:4.8: It’s like a deft carpenter or carpenter’s apprentice. When making a deep cut they know: ‘I’m making a deep cut,’ and when making a shallow cut they know: ‘I’m making a shallow cut.’
translation_text.mn10:5.1: And so they meditate observing an aspect of the body internally, externally, and both internally and externally.
translation_text.mn10:5.2: They meditate observing the body as liable to originate, as liable to fall, and as liable to both originate and vanish.
translation_text.mn10:5.3: Or mindfulness is established that the body exists, to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness. They meditate independent, not grasping at anything in the world.
translation_text.mn10:5.4: That’s how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body.
translation_text.mn10:6.1: Furthermore, when a mendicant is walking they know: ‘I am walking.’ When standing they know: ‘I am standing.’ When sitting they know: ‘I am sitting.’ And when lying down they know: ‘I am lying down.’
translation_text.mn10:6.2: Whatever posture their body is in, they know it.
translation_text.mn10:7.1: And so they meditate observing an aspect of the body internally, externally, and both internally and externally.
translation_text.mn10:7.2: They meditate observing the body as liable to originate, as liable to fall, and as liable to both originate and vanish.
translation_text.mn10:7.3: Or mindfulness is established that the body exists, to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness. They meditate independent, not grasping at anything in the world.
translation_text.mn10:7.4: That too is how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body.
translation_text.mn10:8.1: Furthermore, a mendicant acts with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.
translation_text.mn10:9.1: And so they meditate observing an aspect of the body internally …
translation_text.mn10:9.2: That too is how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body.
translation_text.mn10:10.1: Furthermore, a mendicant examines their own body, up from the soles of the feet and down from the tips of the hairs, wrapped in skin and full of many kinds of filth.
translation_text.mn10:10.2: ‘In this body there is head hair, body hair, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, bones, bone marrow, kidneys, heart, liver, diaphragm, spleen, lungs, intestines, mesentery, undigested food, feces, bile, phlegm, pus, blood, sweat, fat, tears, grease, saliva, snot, synovial fluid, urine.’
translation_text.mn10:10.3: It’s as if there were a bag with openings at both ends, filled with various kinds of grains, such as fine rice, wheat, mung beans, peas, sesame, and ordinary rice. And a person with clear eyes were to open it and examine the contents: ‘These grains are fine rice, these are wheat, these are mung beans, these are peas, these are sesame, and these are ordinary rice.’
translation_text.mn10:11.1: And so they meditate observing an aspect of the body internally …
translation_text.mn10:11.2: That too is how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body.
translation_text.mn10:12.1: Furthermore, a mendicant examines their own body, whatever its placement or posture, according to the elements:
translation_text.mn10:12.2: ‘In this body there is the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element.’
translation_text.mn10:12.3: It’s as if a deft butcher or butcher’s apprentice were to kill a cow and sit down at the crossroads with the meat cut into chops.
translation_text.mn10:13.1: And so they meditate observing an aspect of the body internally …
translation_text.mn10:13.2: That too is how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body.
translation_text.mn10:14.1: Furthermore, suppose a mendicant were to see a corpse discarded in a charnel ground. And it had been dead for one, two, or three days, bloated, livid, and festering.
translation_text.mn10:14.2: They’d compare it with their own body:
translation_text.mn10:14.3: ‘This body is also of that same nature, that same kind, and cannot go beyond that.’
translation_text.mn10:15.1: And so they meditate observing an aspect of the body internally …
translation_text.mn10:15.2: That too is how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body.
translation_text.mn10:16.1: Furthermore, suppose they were to see a corpse discarded in a charnel ground being devoured by crows, hawks, vultures, herons, hounds, tigers, leopards, jackals, and many kinds of little creatures.
translation_text.mn10:16.2: They’d compare it with their own body:
translation_text.mn10:16.3: ‘This body is also of that same nature, that same kind, and cannot go beyond that.’
translation_text.mn10:17.1: And so they meditate observing an aspect of the body internally …
translation_text.mn10:17.2: That too is how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body.
translation_text.mn10:18-23.1: Furthermore, suppose they were to see a corpse discarded in a charnel ground, a skeleton with flesh and blood, held together by sinews …
translation_text.mn10:18-23.2: A skeleton without flesh but smeared with blood, and held together by sinews …
translation_text.mn10:18-23.3: A skeleton rid of flesh and blood, held together by sinews …
translation_text.mn10:24.1: Bones rid of sinews scattered in every direction. Here a hand-bone, there a foot-bone, here an ankle bone, there a shin-bone, here a thigh-bone, there a hip-bone, here a rib-bone, there a back-bone, here an arm-bone, there a neck-bone, here a jaw-bone, there a tooth, here the skull. …
translation_text.mn10:26-28.1: White bones, the color of shells …
translation_text.mn10:29.1: Decrepit bones, heaped in a pile …
translation_text.mn10:30.1: Bones rotted and crumbled to powder.
translation_text.mn10:30.2: They’d compare it with their own body:
translation_text.mn10:30.3: ‘This body is also of that same nature, that same kind, and cannot go beyond that.’
translation_text.mn10:31.1: And so they meditate observing an aspect of the body internally, externally, and both internally and externally.
translation_text.mn10:31.2: They meditate observing the body as liable to originate, as liable to fall, and as liable to both originate and vanish.
translation_text.mn10:31.3: Or mindfulness is established that the body exists, to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness. They meditate independent, not grasping at anything in the world.
translation_text.mn10:31.4: That too is how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body.
translation_text.mn10:32.1: And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of feelings?
translation_text.mn10:32.2: It’s when a mendicant who feels a pleasant feeling knows: ‘I feel a pleasant feeling.’
translation_text.mn10:32.3: When they feel a painful feeling, they know: ‘I feel a painful feeling.’
translation_text.mn10:32.4: When they feel a neutral feeling, they know: ‘I feel a neutral feeling.’
translation_text.mn10:32.5: When they feel a pleasant feeling of the flesh, they know: ‘I feel a pleasant feeling of the flesh.’
translation_text.mn10:32.6: When they feel a pleasant feeling not of the flesh, they know: ‘I feel a pleasant feeling not of the flesh.’
translation_text.mn10:32.7: When they feel a painful feeling of the flesh, they know: ‘I feel a painful feeling of the flesh.’
translation_text.mn10:32.8: When they feel a painful feeling not of the flesh, they know: ‘I feel a painful feeling not of the flesh.’
translation_text.mn10:32.9: When they feel a neutral feeling of the flesh, they know: ‘I feel a neutral feeling of the flesh.’
translation_text.mn10:32.10: When they feel a neutral feeling not of the flesh, they know: ‘I feel a neutral feeling not of the flesh.’
translation_text.mn10:33.1: And so they meditate observing an aspect of feelings internally, externally, and both internally and externally.
translation_text.mn10:33.2: They meditate observing feelings as liable to originate, as liable to fall, and as liable to both originate and vanish.
translation_text.mn10:33.3: Or mindfulness is established that feelings exist, to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness. They meditate independent, not grasping at anything in the world.
translation_text.mn10:33.4: That’s how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of feelings.
translation_text.mn10:34.1: And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of the mind?
translation_text.mn10:34.2: It’s when a mendicant understands mind with greed as ‘mind with greed,’
translation_text.mn10:34.3: and mind without greed as ‘mind without greed.’
translation_text.mn10:34.4: They understand mind with hate as ‘mind with hate,’
translation_text.mn10:34.5: and mind without hate as ‘mind without hate.’
translation_text.mn10:34.6: They understand mind with delusion as ‘mind with delusion,’
translation_text.mn10:34.7: and mind without delusion as ‘mind without delusion.’
translation_text.mn10:34.8: They know constricted mind as ‘constricted mind,’
translation_text.mn10:34.10: They know expansive mind as ‘expansive mind,’
translation_text.mn10:34.12: They know mind that is not supreme as ‘mind that is not supreme,’
translation_text.mn10:34.13: and mind that is supreme as ‘mind that is supreme.’
translation_text.mn10:34.14: They know mind immersed in samādhi as ‘mind immersed in samādhi,’
translation_text.mn10:34.15: and mind not immersed in samādhi as ‘mind not immersed in samādhi.’
translation_text.mn10:34.16: They know freed mind as ‘freed mind,’
translation_text.mn10:35.1: And so they meditate observing an aspect of the mind internally, externally, and both internally and externally.
translation_text.mn10:35.2: They meditate observing the mind as liable to originate, as liable to fall, and as liable to both originate and vanish.
translation_text.mn10:35.3: Or mindfulness is established that the mind exists, to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness. They meditate independent, not grasping at anything in the world.
translation_text.mn10:35.4: That’s how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the mind.
translation_text.mn10:36.1: And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of principles?
translation_text.mn10:36.2: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the five hindrances.
translation_text.mn10:36.3: And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of principles with respect to the five hindrances?
translation_text.mn10:36.4: It’s when a mendicant who has sensual desire in them understands: ‘I have sensual desire in me.’ When they don’t have sensual desire in them, they understand: ‘I don’t have sensual desire in me.’ They understand how sensual desire arises; how, when it’s already arisen, it’s given up; and how, once it’s given up, it doesn’t arise again in the future.
translation_text.mn10:36.5: When they have ill will in them, they understand: ‘I have ill will in me.’ When they don’t have ill will in them, they understand: ‘I don’t have ill will in me.’ They understand how ill will arises; how, when it’s already arisen, it’s given up; and how, once it’s given up, it doesn’t arise again in the future.
translation_text.mn10:36.6: When they have dullness and drowsiness in them, they understand: ‘I have dullness and drowsiness in me.’ When they don’t have dullness and drowsiness in them, they understand: ‘I don’t have dullness and drowsiness in me.’ They understand how dullness and drowsiness arise; how, when they’ve already arisen, they’re given up; and how, once they’re given up, they don’t arise again in the future.
translation_text.mn10:36.7: When they have restlessness and remorse in them, they understand: ‘I have restlessness and remorse in me.’ When they don’t have restlessness and remorse in them, they understand: ‘I don’t have restlessness and remorse in me.’ They understand how restlessness and remorse arise; how, when they’ve already arisen, they’re given up; and how, once they’re given up, they don’t arise again in the future.
translation_text.mn10:36.8: When they have doubt in them, they understand: ‘I have doubt in me.’ When they don’t have doubt in them, they understand: ‘I don’t have doubt in me.’ They understand how doubt arises; how, when it’s already arisen, it’s given up; and how, once it’s given up, it doesn’t arise again in the future.
translation_text.mn10:37.1: And so they meditate observing an aspect of principles internally, externally, and both internally and externally.
translation_text.mn10:37.2: They meditate observing the principles as liable to originate, as liable to fall, and as liable to both originate and vanish.
translation_text.mn10:37.3: Or mindfulness is established that principles exist, to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness. They meditate independent, not grasping at anything in the world.
translation_text.mn10:37.4: That’s how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the five hindrances.
translation_text.mn10:38.1: Furthermore, a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the five grasping aggregates.
translation_text.mn10:38.2: And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of principles with respect to the five grasping aggregates?
translation_text.mn10:38.4: ‘Such is form, such is the origin of form, such is the ending of form.
translation_text.mn10:38.5: Such is feeling, such is the origin of feeling, such is the ending of feeling.
translation_text.mn10:38.6: Such is perception, such is the origin of perception, such is the ending of perception.
translation_text.mn10:38.7: Such are choices, such is the origin of choices, such is the ending of choices.
translation_text.mn10:38.8: Such is consciousness, such is the origin of consciousness, such is the ending of consciousness.’
translation_text.mn10:39.1: And so they meditate observing an aspect of principles internally …
translation_text.mn10:39.4: That’s how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the five grasping aggregates.
translation_text.mn10:40.1: Furthermore, a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the six interior and exterior sense fields.
translation_text.mn10:40.2: And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of principles with respect to the six interior and exterior sense fields?
translation_text.mn10:40.3: It’s when a mendicant understands the eye, sights, and the fetter that arises dependent on both of these. They understand how the fetter that has not arisen comes to arise; how the arisen fetter comes to be abandoned; and how the abandoned fetter comes to not rise again in the future.
translation_text.mn10:40.4: They understand the ear, sounds, and the fetter …
translation_text.mn10:40.5: They understand the nose, smells, and the fetter …
translation_text.mn10:40.6: They understand the tongue, tastes, and the fetter …
translation_text.mn10:40.7: They understand the body, touches, and the fetter …
translation_text.mn10:40.8: They understand the mind, ideas, and the fetter that arises dependent on both of these. They understand how the fetter that has not arisen comes to arise; how the arisen fetter comes to be abandoned; and how the abandoned fetter comes to not rise again in the future.
translation_text.mn10:41.1: And so they meditate observing an aspect of principles internally …
translation_text.mn10:41.4: That’s how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the six interior and exterior sense fields.
translation_text.mn10:42.1: Furthermore, a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the seven awakening factors.
translation_text.mn10:42.2: And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of principles with respect to the seven awakening factors?
translation_text.mn10:42.3: It’s when a mendicant who has the awakening factor of mindfulness in them understands: ‘I have the awakening factor of mindfulness in me.’ When they don’t have the awakening factor of mindfulness in them, they understand: ‘I don’t have the awakening factor of mindfulness in me.’ They understand how the awakening factor of mindfulness that has not arisen comes to arise; and how the awakening factor of mindfulness that has arisen becomes fulfilled by development.
translation_text.mn10:42.4: When they have the awakening factor of investigation of principles …
translation_text.mn10:42.9: equanimity in them, they understand: ‘I have the awakening factor of equanimity in me.’ When they don’t have the awakening factor of equanimity in them, they understand: ‘I don’t have the awakening factor of equanimity in me.’ They understand how the awakening factor of equanimity that has not arisen comes to arise; and how the awakening factor of equanimity that has arisen becomes fulfilled by development.
translation_text.mn10:43.1: And so they meditate observing an aspect of principles internally, externally, and both internally and externally.
translation_text.mn10:43.2: They meditate observing the principles as liable to originate, as liable to fall, and as liable to both originate and vanish.
translation_text.mn10:43.3: Or mindfulness is established that principles exist, to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness. They meditate independent, not grasping at anything in the world.
translation_text.mn10:43.4: That’s how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the seven awakening factors.
translation_text.mn10:44.1: Furthermore, a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the four noble truths.
translation_text.mn10:44.2: And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of principles with respect to the four noble truths?
translation_text.mn10:44.3: It’s when a mendicant truly understands: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
translation_text.mn10:45.1: And so they meditate observing an aspect of principles internally, externally, and both internally and externally.
translation_text.mn10:45.2: They meditate observing the principles as liable to originate, as liable to fall, and as liable to both originate and vanish.
translation_text.mn10:45.3: Or mindfulness is established that principles exist, to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness. They meditate independent, not grasping at anything in the world.
translation_text.mn10:45.4: That’s how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the four noble truths.
translation_text.mn10:46.1: Anyone who develops these four kinds of mindfulness meditation in this way for seven years can expect one of two results:
translation_text.mn10:46.2: enlightenment in this very life, or if there’s something left over, non-return.
translation_text.mn10:46.4: anyone who develops these four kinds of mindfulness meditation in this way for six years …
translation_text.mn10:46.22: anyone who develops these four kinds of mindfulness meditation in this way for seven days can expect one of two results:
translation_text.mn10:46.23: enlightenment in this very life, or if there’s something left over, non-return.
translation_text.mn10:47.1: ‘The four kinds of mindfulness meditation are the path to convergence. They are in order to purify sentient beings, to get past sorrow and crying, to make an end of pain and sadness, to discover the system, and to realize extinguishment.’
translation_text.mn10:47.2: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.”
translation_text.mn10:47.3: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn10:47.4: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
